recipe_xml:
<recipe>
  <title>Baked Snapper with Harissa, New Potatoes, and Spring Onions</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['6 tablespoons olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons harissa paste'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'6 spring onions</ingredient>
    <ingredient>halved lengthwise</ingredient>
    <ingredient>or 8 scallions (left whole)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 pound new potatoes or small potatoes</ingredient>
    <ingredient>scrubbed</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thinly sliced'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Kosher salt</ingredient>
    <ingredient>freshly ground pepper'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 1/2 pound skin-on snapper fillets (3–4)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'lemon wedges (for serving)']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Place an oven rack in upper third of oven</step>
    <step>2. preheat to 425°F. Combine oil and harissa in a small bowl</step>
    <step>3. adjust flavor with more harissa if needed (spiciness and flavor vary from brand to brand).</step>
    <step>4. Toss onions and potatoes with half of harissa mixture in a large baking dish</step>
    <step>5. season with salt and pepper, then add 1/4 cup water. Roast, tossing once, until potatoes are fork-tender, 20–25 minutes. Meanwhile, score skin side of fillets about 1/4" deep</step>
    <step>6. season with salt and pepper. Rub remaining harissa mixture all over fish, getting into the score marks.</step>
    <step>7. Remove onions and potatoes from oven and heat broiler. Place fish skin side up on top of vegetables and broil until onions and potatoes are tender and fish is cooked through and starting to brown on top, 8–10 minutes.</step>
    <step>8. Serve fish and vegetables with lemon wedges for squeezing over.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Sweet Pretzels</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['Master Sweet Dough'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'All-purpose flour (for dusting)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 large egg white'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'6 tablespoons pearl sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'Ingredient info: Pearl sugar</ingredient>
    <ingredient>a coarse sugar used for decorating baked goods</ingredient>
    <ingredient>is available at specialty foods stores and kingarthurflour.com.']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Line 2 large baking sheets with parchment. Punch down dough</step>
    <step>2. divide into 12 equal pieces.</step>
    <step>3. Working with 1 piece at a time and keeping remaining dough covered with a kitchen towel, roll dough on a lightly floured surface into a 17"- long rope. Form rope into a U shape. Lift top of left end</step>
    <step>4. fold over or under opposite side</step>
    <step>5. press together gently about two-thirds down from the top of right side. Lift right end up, fold over, and press in or tuck under, forming a pretzel shape. Repeat with remaining dough. Divide pretzels between sheets, spacing about 2" apart. Loosely cover with plastic wrap or a kitchen towel. Let dough rise in a warm, draft-free area until slightly puffed but not doubled in size, 30-45 minutes.</step>
    <step>6. Meanwhile, arrange racks in upper and lower thirds of oven</step>
    <step>7. preheat to 375°F. Beat egg white and 2 teaspoons warm water in a small bowl. Brush each pretzel all over with egg wash, then sprinkle each with 1/2 tablespoon pearl sugar.</step>
    <step>8. Bake for 10 minutes</step>
    <step>9. rotate baking sheets and continue baking until pretzels are golden, 6-8 minutes longer. Let pretzels cool on a wire rack.</step>
    <step>10. Serve warm or at room temperature.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Spinach Salad with Strawberry Vinaigrette</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['2 1/2 tablespoons strawberry vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'5 ounces baby spinach (8 cups)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 pound strawberries</ingredient>
    <ingredient>cut lengthwise into thick slices (1 1/2 cups)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup pecan halves (3 1/2 ounces)</ingredient>
    <ingredient>toasted and cooled']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Whisk together vinegar, a rounded 1/4 teaspoon salt, and 1/8 teaspoon pepper in a small bowl, then add oil in a slow stream, whisking well. Put spinach, strawberries, and pecans in a large bowl and toss with just enough vinaigrette to lightly coat.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Baccalà Mantecato: A Savory Spread of Whipped Salt Cod</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['1 pound boneless baccalà (salt cod)</ingredient>
    <ingredient>soaked to remove salt'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 medium russet potato (about 1/2 pound)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 plump garlic cloves</ingredient>
    <ingredient>finely minced'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup extra-virgin olive oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup half-and-half or light cream'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/2 cup poaching water from cooking the baccalà'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'freshly ground black pepper to taste'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'A heavy-duty electric mixer with the paddle attachment or a food processor']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. When the baccalà is sufficiently soaked, cut it into small pieces—6 inches or so—and put them in a saucepan or deep skillet with at least an inch of water to cover. Bring to a boil, set the cover ajar (rest it on a wooden spoon set on the rim of the pan), and cook at a steady bubbling boil for 20 minutes or more, until the cod is easy to flake but still has body and shape. Don't let it start to break apart. Lift it out of the cooking water, and let it drain and cool in a colander. Reserve a cup of the cooking water.</step>
    <step>2. Meanwhile, rinse the potato but leave it whole and unpeeled. Put it in a small pot covered with cold water. Bring to the boil, and cook steadily until you can easily pierce the potato with a knife blade.</step>
    <step>3. Let it cool, and peel it.</step>
    <step>4. Set up the electric mixer and flake all the fish into the bowl. Beat with the paddle at low speed to break the fish up more</step>
    <step>5. drop in the minced garlic, and beat at medium speed while you pour in half the olive oil very gradually in a thin stream, then add the potato and incorporate it</step>
    <step>6. continue beating at low speed as you gradually add the rest of the oil.</step>
    <step>7. Now raise the speed to high and whip the fish to lighten it.</step>
    <step>8. Reduce the speed to medium and incorporate the half-and- half gradually, then whip at high speed again. At this point the whipped cod should be smooth and fluffy, almost like mashed potatoes but with texture. If it is very dense, you can thin it with the cooking water (but be careful: too much water will make it too salty).</step>
    <step>9. Finally, season with pepper and beat it in to blend. If you use a food processor instead of a mixer, follow the same order of additions, and process as needed to form a light, smooth spread. Put the spread in containers and store sealed, in the refrigerator, for up to a week. You can also freeze baccalà mantecato</step>
    <step>10. the texture will not be as creamy, but it will have good flavor and makes a delicious pasta sauce.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>

<recipe>
  <title>Bean Thread Noodles with Pickled Vegetables</title>
  <ingredients>
    <ingredient>['6 ounces wide bean thread noodles'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 small garlic clove</ingredient>
    <ingredient>finely grated'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup fish sauce (such as nam pla or nuoc nam)'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3 tablespoons fresh lime juice'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 tablespoons unseasoned rice vinegar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 tablespoon sugar'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 teaspoons finely grated peeled ginger'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 large daikon (Japanese white radish; about 1 pound)</ingredient>
    <ingredient>julienned'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 English hothouse cucumber</ingredient>
    <ingredient>thinly sliced'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'2 large carrots</ingredient>
    <ingredient>peeled</ingredient>
    <ingredient>julienned'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1/4 cup vegetable oil'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'1 cup torn fresh cilantro</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'3/4 cup unsalted</ingredient>
    <ingredient>dry-roasted peanuts</ingredient>
    <ingredient>coarsely chopped</ingredient>
    <ingredient>divided'</ingredient>
    <ingredient>'ingredient info: Bean thread noodles and daikon can be found at Asian markets and some supermarkets.']</ingredient>
  </ingredients>
  <instructions>
    <step>1. Place noodles in a large bowl and add boiling water to cover. Let noodles soak until tender but not mushy, 15-20 minutes</step>
    <step>2. drain. Rinse under cold water and drain well.</step>
    <step>3. Whisk garlic, fish sauce, lime juice, vinegar, sugar, ginger, and pepper in another large bowl. Add daikon, cucumber, and carrots</step>
    <step>4. toss to combine. Let sit 10 minutes.</step>
    <step>5. Add noodles, oil, half of cilantro, and half of peanuts to bowl</step>
    <step>6. toss to combine. Top salad with remaining cilantro and peanuts.</step>
    <step>7. DO AHEAD: Vegetables can be pickled 2 days ahead. Cover and chill.</step>
  </instructions>
</recipe>
